title: Ayman Zohry
text:
Ayman Zohry (born June 7, 1964) is a <a href="demography">demographer</a>/<a href="geographer">geographer</a> and expert on migration studies based in <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a>, <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>. He was born in <a href="Souhag">Souhag</a>, <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>. Zohry received his <a href="Doctor%20of%20Philosophy">Ph.D.</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20Sussex">University of Sussex</a> in 2002. He is a leading researcher in the field of migration studies in <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> with a special focus on <a href="irregular%20immigration">irregular migration</a>.
Dr. Zohry has about 20 years of experience in the field of population studies and migration research. He started his career working as a junior demographer at the National Population Council (Egypt) from 1987 until joining the <a href="Cairo%20Demographic%20Center">Cairo Demographic Center</a> in 1992 to study for two diplomas in <a href="demography">demography</a> and <a href="population">population</a> and development, then a <a href="Master%20of%20Philosophy">Master of Philosophy</a> in <a href="Demography">Demography</a> in 1995 with specialization in <a href="family%20planning">family planning</a> programs and population policies. While studying at CDC he worked as a lecturer assistant, <a href="lecturer">lecturer</a>, and trainer. He was also a lecturer in the <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a>-sponsored Population and Development Program also. He carried out a lot of studies in his field of specialization and he used an array of Demographic and Health Surveys for countries of <a href="Africa">Africa</a> and <a href="Asia">Asia</a>. He moved then to work in a <a href="United%20Nations%20Population%20Fund">UNFPA</a>-funded project in the field of strengthening <a href="Non-governmental%20organization">NGOs</a> working in the field of population. In 1997 he joined the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">US Naval</a> Medical Research Unit in <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a> (NAMRU-3), <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a> as a <a href="Data%20analysis">data analyst</a> working in the field of medical demography and infant and child <a href="disease">disease</a>s. In 1999 he joined a project implemented by the <a href="Academy%20for%20Educational%20Development">Academy for Educational Development</a> (AED), a <a href="United%20States">United States</a> organization and he used to work as the director of Monitoring and Evaluation division.
In the last few years he worked as a <a href="visiting%20scholar">visiting professor</a> at <a href="American%20University%20of%20Beirut">American University of Beirut</a> (AUB), <a href="American%20University%20in%20Cairo">American University in Cairo</a> (AUB), and <a href="http%3A//www.diis.dk/">The Danish Institute for International Studies</a>. In addition, he carried out consulting work in the fields of demography, education, labor force, and migration for the <a href="International%20Organization%20for%20Migration">International Organization for Migration</a> (IOM), <a href="World%20Bank%20Group">World Bank</a>, <a href="Arab%20League">Arab League</a>, <a href="United%20Nations%20Economic%20and%20Social%20Commission%20for%20Western%20Asia">United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia</a>, <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>, <a href="Academy%20for%20Educational%20Development">Academy for Educational Development</a>, <a href="United%20States%20Agency%20of%20International%20Development">United States Agency of International Development</a> (USAID), and many other national, regional, and international organizations. Currently, Dr. Zohry's work focuses on migration with special emphasis on <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20110527033031/http%3A//www.diis.dk/graphics/Publications/WP2006/WP2006-18_web.pdf">illegal migration of Egyptian youth to Europe</a>. Most of Dr. Zohry's published work is available for download at <a href="http%3A//www.zohry.com/">his website</a>. His <a href="http%3A//www.zohry.com/pubs/insights/">recent book </a> "Insights into Egyptian Society" was published in <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a> in 2006.
